data.title: Every single Matt Damon movie, ranked
data.meta_description: Matt Damon is known for his roles in "Good Will Hunting," "Air," and "Oppenheimer," but he's also starred in movies like "Ponyo" and "Happy Feet Two."
data.text:
This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now. Have an account? .

Matt Damon is known for his award-winning role in "Good Will Hunting."

Some of Damon's highest-reviewed films include "Saving Private Ryan" and "Ponyo."

Other films, like "Suburbicon" and "The Third Wheel," didn't rate as well with critics.

Advertisement

Matt Damon's lowest-rated film, according to critics, is "Suburbicon" (2017).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 28%

Summary: In the seemingly perfect town of Suburbicon, a family faces a violent tragedy and the dark underbelly of their community is exposed, shattering the illusion of suburban bliss.

Critics disliked the film due to its mixed themes and were generally disappointed in director George Clooney.

"A strong cast and talented director never make the whole add up," wrote Ian Freer of the film for Empire magazine.

Advertisement

Damon played James Granger in "The Monuments Men" (2014).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 31%

Summary: During World War II, a group of art expert historians known as the Monuments Men embark on a daring mission to rescue priceless cultural treasures stolen by the Nazis, risking their lives to preserve humanity's cultural heritage.

Most reviewers thought the film had good intentions and a strong cast, but failed to deliver on the story.

As critic Chris Stuckmann wrote in a review for his site, "I respect the inspiring story being told, but the film's screenplay doesn't have the necessary weight in its pages, or the depth in its characters."

Advertisement

He starred as John Grady Cole in "All the Pretty Horses" (2000).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 32%

Summary: A young cowboy named John Grady Cole (Damon) encounters love, danger, and self-discovery while exploring the challenges of the Old West on a journey through Mexico.

The film was not well-received, with critics feeling no chemistry between Damon and his costar Penélope Cruz. Many reviewers thought it was a poor adaption of the Cormac McCarthy novel it was based on.

"McCarthy's novel employs the coming of age narrative in service of his sanguineous spiritual vision," wrote Steve Mirarchi for the Boston Globe. "For the film to renounce that philosophy is to give up its soul and be rendered lifeless."

Advertisement

Damon played Kevin in "The Third Wheel" (2002).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 33%

Summary: A lonely office worker's life takes an unexpected turn when he inadvertently becomes the unwanted third wheel on a date. Hilarity ensues as he navigates awkward situations and attempts to find his own happiness.

Although some critics liked the performances by leads Luke Wilson and Denise Richards, many reviewers believed the film was only ever made due to the recent success of the two stars of the movie, Damon and Ben Affleck.

Per Reel Film Reviews, David Nusair wrote that the movie "often feels more like a second-rate sitcom than an actual movie."

Advertisement

The actor was William Garin in "The Great Wall" (2016).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 35%

Summary: A group of European mercenaries are in a battle against ancient monsters while defending the Great Wall of China. They must unite with Chinese warriors to save humanity from a terrifying threat lurking beyond the wall.

Despite the movie's detail, critics disliked Damon as the lead in an Asian film and wanted more from the plot.

"The movie is a muddled monster mash that's as disappointing as it is insignificant," wrote Sara Michelle Fetters for MovieFreak.com.

Advertisement

"The Brothers Grimm" (2005) featured Damon as Wilhelm Grimm.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 38%

Summary: Two con artist brothers, Wilhelm (Damon) and Jacob Grimm (Heath Ledger), encounter real supernatural forces when they are forced to confront a cursed forest where fairy tales come to life, putting their wit and bravery to the ultimate test.

Although the film was hailed for its vivid fairy-tale imagery, the majority of critics thought the script was disappointing and messy.

"'The Brothers Grimm' has enough haunting, fairy-tale imagery for 10 movies, but no emotional kick to drive those images home," wrote David Edelstein in his review for Slate.

Advertisement

In "Jersey Girl" (2014), Damon had a small role as a PR executive.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 43%

Summary: A successful New York publicist's life is turned upside down when his wife tragically dies during childbirth. Forced to raise his daughter alone in New Jersey, he learns the true meaning of fatherhood, love, and finding happiness in unexpected places.

Reviewers were very critical of Ben Affleck's leading performance in "Jersey Girl." Generally, they enjoyed the movie's warm tone but thought it verged on being too sentimental.

For the Austin Chronicle, Kimberley Jones wrote of the movie, "Its heart is in the right place. Unfortunately, that heart is about the only element here that doesn't strain credibility."

Advertisement

In "The Legend of Bagger Vance" (2000), Damon starred as Rannulph Junuh.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 43%

Summary: A golfer in the midst of a personal crisis finds redemption when he encounters a mysterious caddy who teaches him about the power of faith, self-discovery, and the true spirit of the game.

Critics thought the film was full of talented actors, including Damon, Will Smith, and Charlize Theron, but most reviewers ultimately deemed the characters to be flat.

"Another lusciously produced, emotionally clammy Redford enterprise — forced, phony mythmaking filled with tinged sunsets and full moons," wrote Peter Rainer for New York Magazine/Vulture.

Advertisement

He was the voice of Bill the Krill in "Happy Feet Two" (2011).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 45%

Summary: The penguin nation faces a new threat as its home is disrupted by an enormous iceberg. Mumble's (voiced by Elijah Wood) son must find his own unique voice to unite the penguins and other creatures in an epic journey.

Although most reviewers agreed the film's animation was detailed and vibrant, most thought it didn't live up to the original.

Derek Adams wrote for Time Out, "If there's a saving grace, it's the visuals, especially the beautiful scenes of orange krill. But that's about all."

Advertisement

In "Downsizing" (2017), Damon played Paul Safranek.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 47%

Summary: Paul Safranek (Damon) decides to undergo a groundbreaking procedure that shrinks him and his wife down to 5 inches as a solution to overpopulation and environmental concerns. Their new life in a miniature world brings unexpected adventures and challenges that force them to question everything.

Critics thought the movie had a great concept but ultimately failed to deliver on it.

"It offers a jumble of barely explored, quarter-baked ideas attached to a laborious plot," wrote Deborah Ross for The Spectator.

Advertisement

He played Donny in "Eurotrip" (2004).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 47%

Summary: A group of American teenagers embarks on a hilarious and wild adventure across Europe after a miscommunication leads them to believe that one of them has found a romantic interest overseas.

The film's reviews were generally split between critics who thought it was wild in an entertaining way and those who felt the humor wasn't worth the film's raunchiness.

"Basically this is pretty lame, but if you like soft core jokes about breasts, booze and stoopid behaviour, Eurotrip will not disappoint," wrote Kaleem Aftab for The List.

Advertisement

Damon is featured in "Hereafter" (2010) as George Lonegan.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 47%

Summary: An American psychic (Damon), a French journalist (Cécile de France), and a London schoolboy (Frankie and George McLaren) find their lives interconnected as they grapple with the concept of mortality and the afterlife, seeking answers and solace in their own unique ways.

Generally, the film's premise was well-received, but critics thought it was disappointing and hokey.

Anthony Quinn reviewed the film for the Independent (UK), writing, "It is sincere, well-meaning and, I'm sorry to say, quite transparent hokum."

Advertisement

The actor played Lt. Britton Davis in "Geronimo: An American Legend" (1993).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 48%

Summary: Legendary Apache leader Geronimo (Wes Studi) resists the encroachment of white settlers on Indigenous lands in the late 19th century.

The film was liked by some critics for its well-shot historical depictions, but many thought it fell flat in terms of excitement and plot.

"Despite the film's visual and aural splendors," wrote Malcolm Johnson for the Hartford Courant. "'Geronimo' fails to achieve its noble ambitions."

Advertisement

"The Zero Theorem" (2013) stars Damon as Management.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 48%

Summary: A reclusive computer genius is tasked with solving a mathematical formula that holds the key to the meaning of life.

Reviews for the movie were split, with nearly half of the critics enjoying the vision of director Terry Gilliam and many feeling the film was jumbled and manic.

"It's bursting with Gilliam's trademark manic energy, but the focus and execution are so soft that that energy ends up derailing the film instead of invigorating it," wrote Barbara VanDenburgh of the film in a review for the Arizona Republic.

Advertisement

In "Titan A.E.'' (2000), Damon was the voice of Cale.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 50%

Summary: A young man named Cale Tucker (voiced by Damon) becomes humanity's last hope for survival when Earth is destroyed by an alien race.

The reviews on "Titan A.E." were split nearly in half. Those who enjoyed the movie praised the film's cast, animation, and effects, while those who disliked it thought it wasn't quite original enough.

Grant Watson called the movie "an uneven blend of success and failure" in his review for Fiction Machine.

Advertisement

Damon appeared as himself and Will Hunting in "Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back" (2001).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 52%

Summary: Jay (Jason Mewes) and Silent Bob (Kevin Smith) embark on a cross-country mission to Hollywood to stop a film adaptation of their comic book alter egos.

Critics thought the film was raunchy and self-indulgent, appealing primarily to fans of Smith's previous films. Some thought it relied too heavily on inside jokes and references.

"A cross between a crude dumbed-down comedy and a home movie featuring a couple of dozen guest appearances by various performers and celebrities," wrote Philip French of the film for The Guardian.

Advertisement

Damon starred as Roy Miller in "Green Zone" (2010).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 53%

Summary: An Army officer in Iraq uncovers a web of corruption and misinformation during the search for weapons of mass destruction. As he seeks the truth, he becomes a target and must navigate a dangerous landscape to expose the real agenda.

Though some reviewers felt the film was gripping thanks to its intense action sequences and Damon's performance, others criticized it for its heavy-handed anti-war message.

"It's one thing for the filmmakers to (sort of) fictionalize real people," wrote Peter Rainer for Christian Science Monitor. "But 'Green Zone' wraps up with a wish-fulfillment fantasy that is about as believable as watching reinforcements riding in to save Custer."

Advertisement

Damon produced "Promised Land" (2012) and appeared in it as Steve Butler.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 53%

Summary: A corporate salesman arrives in a small town to negotiate land rights for natural-gas drilling, facing unexpected challenges and moral dilemmas along the way.

Many critics enjoyed that the film was thought-provoking and had strong performances, but some reviewers criticized it for its lack of subtlety in its messaging and predictable plot twists.

Kent Jones reviewed the movie for Film Comment magazine, writing, "Damon and Krasinski's script isn't completely solid, but it follows a believably wayward path to a lovely, muted ending."

Advertisement

Damon starred as the titular character in "Jason Bourne" (2016).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 54%

Summary: Jason Bourne (Damon) resurfaces when new information about his past emerges. Hunted by the agency he once served, Bourne embarks on a relentless pursuit of the truth while evading capture.

Although the "Jason Bourne" franchise is generally well-loved by critics, reviewers felt this installment was a somewhat underwhelming addition, citing its lackluster plot and usual "Bourne" tropes. However, it was enjoyed by other reviewers for its high-impact action sequences.

Dwight Brown reviewed the film for the National Newspaper Publishers Association, writing, "One hour into the movie, you feel like you're watching outtakes from a Mission Impossible sequel."

Advertisement

In "Ocean's Twelve" (2004), Damon starred as Linus Caldwell.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 55%

Summary: Danny Ocean (George Clooney) and his team reunite for another daring heist after being blackmailed by a cunning European thief. They must outsmart both law enforcement and their newfound adversary to pull off the ultimate con.

Critics described this installment of the "Ocean's" franchise as an entertaining heist film with a star-studded cast, but some didn't enjoy its convoluted plot and lack of tension compared to the original.

"'Ocean's Twelve' is busier, messier and thinner than its predecessor," wrote David Ansen of the sequel for Newsweek. "While it looks like the cast is having a blast and a half, the studied hipness can get so pleased with itself it borders on the smug."

Advertisement

"The Good Shepherd" (2006) featured Damon as Edward Wilson.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 56%

Summary: An idealistic Yale student is recruited by the newly formed CIA and becomes deeply entrenched in the world of espionage. As he rises through the ranks, he grapples with loyalty, sacrifice, and the blurred lines between duty and personal life.

Reviews of the film were split between critics who thought it was a well-crafted and intelligent spy thriller and others who said it had a slow pace and confusing plot.

"In a mystery worthy of the CIA, 'The Good Shepherd' ends up being both too long and too short," wrote Brian Tallerico for UGO.

Advertisement

The actor played Charlie Dillon in "School Ties" (1992).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 60%

Summary: A talented Jewish student named David Greene (Brendan Fraser) earns a scholarship to a prestigious New England prep school. Facing prejudice and betrayal, he must confront his identity and navigate the complexities of friendship in a divided community.

Many reviewers enjoyed the movie, commending its themes, acting, and thought-provoking nature. Others noted that the plot was predictable and at times melodramatic.

Matt Mueller reviewed the film for Empire magazine, writing, "The boys put in fine performances but sadly the script lacks the depth of what could have been a challenging story."

Advertisement

Damon was a writer for and starred as one of the two titular characters in "Gerry" (2002).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 61%

Summary: Two friends with identical names, Gerry (Damon) and Gerry (Casy Affleck) find themselves lost in the desert with no sense of direction. Their friendship is tested as they face existential challenges that push the boundaries of their endurance and perception of reality.

Critics felt the movie was unconventional but benefited from its unique vision. Some reviewers didn't like the film's slow pacing.

As Nick Schager wrote for Lessons of Darkness, the movie was "absolutely transfixing at one moment and unbearably boring the next."

Advertisement

"Stuck on You" (2003) showcased Damon as Bob Tenor.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 61%

Summary: A pair of conjoined twins (Damon and Greg Kinnear) live a close-knit life, but their desire for individuality leads them on a hilarious and heartwarming journey.

Many critics thought the film was a lighthearted comedy with good entertainment from its lead actors, but nearly half of them criticized the movie for its uneven humor and reliance on physical gags.

"What first feels like thin skit material gets funnier and sweeter," David Ansen wrote for Newsweek. "Damon and Kinnear make a terrific team."

Advertisement

In "Elysium" (2013), the actor played Max DeCosta.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 64%

Summary: Set in a future where the wealthy live on a luxurious space station called Elysium while the rest suffer on an overpopulated Earth, one man named Max DeCosta (Damon) dares to challenge the oppressive system in a dangerous mission that could bring equality to both worlds.

The film was generally favored by critics thanks to its visually stunning effects and world-building. Some criticized the lack of character development, claiming it resulted in a film that fell short of its potential despite its visual spectacle.

Kevin Maher wrote for the Times (UK) that the movie's "visuals are breathtaking and there's a mid-movie shoot'em-up that's one of the best in the genre."

Advertisement

The star played Loki in "Jay and Silent Bob Reboot" (2019).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 64%

Summary: Jay and Silent Bob embark on a cross-country journey to Hollywood once again, this time to stop the reboot of a movie based on their lives.

Most reviewers described the reboot as nostalgic, self-aware, and fresh — ideal for fans of the original characters and original director Kevin Smith.

"Smith has every right to be older and wiser here," wrote Owen Gleiberman for Variety. "With its gentle anarchy and not-quite-mock nostalgia, is a time-machine sequel that passes the time amiably enough."

Advertisement

Mike McDermott was Damon's character in "Rounders" (1998).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 64%

Summary: A reformed gambler and law student finds himself drawn back into the underground world of high-stakes poker to help his friend repay a debt.

More reviewers than not praised the movie for its gripping and authentic universe with strong performances. But some felt the movie was too niche and the plot was thin.

"John Dahl creates an intelligent and character-driven crime-drama built around solid performances by Damon and Norton," wrote Jon Fortgang in a review for Film4.

Advertisement

In "We Bought a Zoo" (2011), the star played Benjamin Mee.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 64%

Summary: A widowed father decides to make a fresh start with his children by purchasing a dilapidated zoo.

Reviewers described the movie as a heartwarming family drama, anchored by a stellar performance by Damon, though many acknowledged the movie had an overly sentimental tone and predictable plot.

"Everything is, indeed, tied up exactly the way you know it will be tied up, because it is that sort of film," wrote Deborah Ross for The Spectator. "But it still provides a perfectly agreeable way to spend the two hours you weren't going to do anything with anyway."

Advertisement

He played Loki in "Dogma" (1999).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 67%

Summary: Two fallen angels, Loki (Damon) and Bartleby (Ben Affleck), embark on a mission to exploit a loophole in Catholic doctrine that could grant them salvation.

Though controversial, particularly in the eyes of some audience members who could see the film as blasphemous, many critics thought the film nailed the satirical tone and had strong performances to support its provocative subject.

"Dogma is both one of the worst movies ever made and also one of the best," wrote Clement Tyler Obropta for Film Inquiry.

Advertisement

"American Teacher" (2011) was narrated by Damon.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 69%

Summary: In this documentary, the challenges, triumphs, and sacrifices faced by teachers in the American education system are explored through personal stories and interviews.

Nearly 70% of critics enjoyed the documentary, calling it a compelling and eye-opening story that sheds light on the challenges and lack of appreciation faced by teachers in America.

In a review for the Los Angeles Times, Kenneth Turan wrote, "As we watch the individuals in 'American Teacher' struggle with the burdens the system places on them, it's hard not to feel like crying, both for them specifically and for our national culture."

Advertisement

Damon voiced Spirit in "Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron" (2002).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 69%

Summary: A wild Mustang horse named Spirit (Damon) defies captivity and embarks on a courageous journey to return to his herd and homeland.

Critics thought the movie had breathtaking animation, sweeping visuals, and an emotional story that appealed to both children and adults.

"There's nothing thrilling or new about the work here, but accomplished it is," wrote Todd McCarthy for Variety.

Advertisement

In "Ocean's Thirteen" (2007), Damon reprised his role as Linus Caldwell.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 70%

Summary: Danny Ocean (Clooney) and his team of skilled criminals reunite for a new heist after their friend is double-crossed by a ruthless casino owner.

Nearly three-quarters of praised reviewers felt the film was a solid return to the franchise, though not quite as good as the original.

"When a movie keeps you this entertained without insulting your intelligence, it's hard to complain," wrote Rene Rodriguez for the Miami Herald.

Advertisement

The documentary "Radioman" (2012) featured Damon as himself.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 71%

Summary: This documentary film follows the extraordinary life of Radioman, a beloved and enigmatic New York City character who has become an iconic figure in the film industry.

Critics enjoyed the heartfelt interviews from actors in the documentary and felt it was a solid portrayal of the legendary character with an interesting look inside the business of film.

Nigel Andrews of the Financial Times called the film "a pleasantly cuckoo story."

Advertisement

In "The Adjustment Bureau" (2011), the actor played David Norris.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 71%

Summary: A charismatic politician named David Norris (Damon) discovers the existence of a mysterious organization that controls people's destinies.

The film received mostly positive reviews for its captivating sci-fi premise, though some critics felt the romantic subplot was contrived.

"It's a fresh look at a familiar city. But Nolfi drops the ball in the home stretch," wrote Leonard Maltin for IndieWire.

Advertisement

"Interstellar" (2014) starred Damon as Dr. Mann.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 73%

Summary: Earth faces an existential crisis as a group of astronauts embarks on a perilous journey through a newly discovered wormhole in search of a habitable planet for humanity's survival.

The film received critical acclaim for its visually stunning space visuals, emotional storytelling, and interesting exploration of humanity.

"Staggeringly beautiful, bafflingly complex, this is proper event cinema," wrote Wendy Ide for Times (UK).

Advertisement

He appeared as Bryan Woodman in "Syriana" (2005).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 73%

Summary: The intricate web of global politics, corruption, and oil interests is unraveled through multiple interconnected storylines.

The film was praised by critics for its intriguing portrayal of the oil industry and gripping plot.

"Syriana is an American movie that reaches out beyond itself. Watching it made me feel hopeful — a rare sensation in a cinema," wrote Zadie Smith for the Daily Telegraph (UK).

Advertisement

Damon was Mr. Aaron in "Margaret" (2011).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 75%

Summary: A teenage girl named Lisa (Anna Paquin) witnesses a tragic accident and becomes embroiled in its aftermath.

Three-quarters of critics enjoyed the film, citing the script's ambitious storytelling, the cast's powerful acting, and the complex subject matter.

"It has its flaws, but I defy you to find a more intelligent or impassioned American film this year," wrote Leonard Maltin for leonardmaltin.com.

Advertisement

"Stillwater" showcased Damon as Bill Baker (2021).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 75%

Summary: An American oil rig roughneck travels to Marseille, France, to support his daughter, who has been imprisoned for a crime she claimed she didn't commit.

The film received mixed reviews, but many were favorable due primarily to Damon's performance and the film's emotional depth.

"This is a thoughtful, knotty character study, albeit one nestled inside a polished, and less interesting, action thriller," wrote Simran Hans for the Observer (UK).

Advertisement

In "Invictus" (2009), Francois Pienaar was played by Damon.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 76%

Summary: Nelson Mandela (Morgan Freeman), newly elected as South Africa's president, aims to unite a racially divided nation through the unifying power of rugby.

Reviewers were mostly positive about the film, with critics enjoying the inspirational story, star-studded work by Damon and Freeman, and the movie's ability to capture the spirit of unity.

Ed Koch reviewed the film for The Atlantic, writing, "Morgan Freeman's portrayal of Nelson Mandela creates a superb moment in time on the movie screen."

Advertisement

In "The Informant!" (2009), Mark Whitacre was played by Damon.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 79%

Summary: Mark Whitacre (Damon), a high-ranking executive at a major corporation, becomes an FBI informant in a price-fixing investigation. However, as the case unfolds, Whitacre's credibility and motives come into question.

The film received primarily positive reviews thanks to the darkly comedic tone, Damon's standout acting, and its exploration of corporate corruption.

"Although not a blockbuster, 'The Informant!' is an interesting, diverting film," wrote Ed Koch for The Atlantic.

Advertisement

He appears in "Confessions of a Dangerous Mind" (2002) as Bachelor #2.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 80%

Summary: A game0show producer leads a double life as a CIA operative, balancing his espionage activities with the creation of popular TV shows.

Critics applauded the movie's imaginative storytelling, direction by Clooney, and ability to blend reality and fiction.

"The film does not offer any explanations," wrote Namrata Joshi in a review for Outlook. "Instead, it intrigues more."

Advertisement

Damon appeared as himself in the documentary "Clerk" (2021).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 82%

Summary: This documentary details the work and personal life of filmmaker Kevin Smith.

Although some critics felt the film didn't offer anything more than previous documentaries about Smith, most agreed it was a fun watch.

"It proves time and again that Smith's career is one worth considering, celebrating, and continuing to follow," wrote Becca James for the Chicago Reader.

Advertisement

The actor played Rudy Baylor in "The Rainmaker" (1997).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 82%

Summary: A young and idealistic lawyer takes on a powerful insurance company in a legal battle that could make or break his career.

The reviews for this film showed high praise for the cast, but there was some criticism for occasional clichés.

"A wonderfully quirky cast under Francis Ford Coppola's direction makes this one of the more enjoyable Grisham movies," wrote David Ansen for Newsweek.

Advertisement

Damon continued his role as Jason Bourne in "The Bourne Supremacy" (2004).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 82%

Summary: Jason Bourne (Damon) seeks revenge for the death of his girlfriend while evading the CIA.

Although some reviews claimed the film was not as impactful as the original, most of the critics felt the movie was a top-notch thriller with great storytelling.

Nell Minow of Common Sense Media called the sequel a "smooth but violent thriller."

Advertisement

Damon starred in "Ocean's Eleven" (2001) as Linus Caldwell.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 83%

Summary: Danny Ocean (Clooney) assembles a team of skilled criminals to pull off an audacious heist on three of the biggest casinos in Las Vegas, complete with elaborate plans and clever tactics.

Notoriously regarded as the best in the series, "Ocean's Eleven" was admired by critics for its sophisticated heist plot, charismatic ensemble cast, and director Steven Soderbergh's unique touch.

"Is Ocean's Eleven the coolest film ever made?" asked Brian Eggert in a review for Deep Focus Review. "It's certainly a contender," he answered.

Advertisement

Damon played Redneck #2 in "Deadpool 2" (2018).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 84%

Summary: Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) returns for another action-packed adventure in which he forms a team of fellow mutants called X-Force to protect a young mutant from a time-traveling soldier.

Like the first, this installment of the "Deadpool" franchise was well-received by critics thanks to its irreverent humor, over-the-top action sequences, and Reynolds' charismatic character.

Anupama Chopra reviewed the movie for Film Companion, writing, "If you like your cinema understated and refined, then this is not for you. But for the rest of us, there's enough to enjoy here."

Advertisement

"The Bourne Identity" (2002) starred Damon as Jason Bourne.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 84%

Summary: Jason Bourne (Damon) is found floating unconscious in the sea with no memory of his identity. As he pieces together his past, he discovers he is a highly trained CIA operative hunted by those who want him silenced.

The first of the "Bourne" franchise is considered the best by many reviewers' standards. The series was set for success with the film's thrilling action sequences, engaging storyline, and Damon's exciting acting.

Todd McCarthy of Variety wrote that the film was "a first-rate thriller with grit and intrigue to spare."

Advertisement

In "Contagion" (2011), the actor played Mitch Emhoff.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 85%

Summary: A deadly and highly contagious virus spreads rapidly across the globe, causing panic and chaos. Scientists race against time to find a cure as governments struggle to maintain order.

Critics thought the film was an exceptional and scary disaster movie, particularly thanks to its strong ensemble cast.

"The all-star disaster-movie genre is taken out of the 1970s and given a stylish and largely persuasive 21st century makeover by director and cinematographer Steven Soderbergh," wrote Peter Bradshaw for The Guardian.

Advertisement

Damon was an executive producer, writer, and character Jean de Carrouges in "The Last Duel" (2021).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 85%

Summary: Set in 14th-century France, two knights, Jean de Carrouges (Damon) and Jacques Le Gris (Adam Driver), engage in a fierce and consequential duel to settle a dispute.

Most reviewers felt the film was intriguing and enthralling, thanks to the all-star cast.

"'The Last Duel' is a big screen experience if ever there was one and, for the most part, a pretty impressive one," wrote David Stratton for The Australian.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Advertisement

He starred in "The Departed" (2006) as Colin Sullivan.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 91%

Summary: An undercover cop infiltrates a Boston mob syndicate while a mobster infiltrates the Massachusetts State Police.

Highly regarded as one of the best in its genre, the film was praised by nearly all critics for its talented cast, intense thrills, and masterful direction by Martin Scorsese.

"'The Departed' is an example of a cinematic master seeking to live up to the veneration with which he is regarded by his pupils," wrote Sukhdev Sandhu for Daily Telegraph (UK).

Advertisement

Damon was Mark Watney in"The Martian" (2015).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 91%

Summary: An astronaut is stranded on Mars after his crew mistakenly believes him to be dead during an intense storm. Alone and with limited resources, Mark Watney (Damon) must use his ingenuity and resilience to survive and find a way to signal Earth for rescue.

The film received critical acclaim for its gripping survival narrative and Damon's charisma.

"It's just a cracklingly good entertainment, a crowd-pleaser that's compelling and emotional and even a little inspirational," wrote Jason Bailey for Flavorwire.

Advertisement

"Air" (2023) featured Damon as Sonny Vaccaro.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 92%

Summary: Nike takes a gamble and partners with rookie Michael Jordan (Damian Young) in an effort to save the brand's failing basketball division.

Reviewers thoroughly enjoyed the movie's quick pacing, anchored by wonderful portrayals and a great real-life story.

Udita Jhunjhunwala called the film "a quick-paced entertainer with glib dialogue, humour and a wonderful sense of nostalgia for the 1980s" in a review for Scroll.in.

Advertisement

In "Ford v Ferrari" (2019), Damon played Carroll Shelby.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 92%

Summary: An automotive designer and driver work together to build a revolutionary race car for Ford Motor Company.

The film was praised by critics for its exhilarating race sequences, expert direction, and dynamic characters.

"You see the concentration. You see the sweat. You see the danger. You see the madness," wrote Stephen Romei for The Australian.

Advertisement

Damon reprised his leading role in "The Bourne Ultimatum" (2007).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 92%

Summary: Jason Bourne (Damon), a former CIA operative, continues his quest to uncover the truth about his past.

Widely considered one of the best in the franchise, the film was received as a satisfying and thrilling conclusion to the trilogy.

"If it feels like a non-stop demolition derby, at least there's a responsible driver at the wheel," wrote Ryan Gilbey in a review for the New Statesman. "Paul Greengrass makes everything seem more plausible with twitchy camerawork and even twitchier editing."

Advertisement

"Behind the Candelabra" (2013) showcased Damon as Scott Thorson.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 94%

Summary: The life and relationship of renowned pianist Liberace (Michael Douglas) and his young lover (Damon) are explored.

The combination of Soderbergh's direction, complex performances from Douglas and Damon, and the impressive depiction of a musical icon made the film a hit.

"Yes. It is fabulous. No other word for it, unless that word is 'glorious,'" wrote Deborah Ross of the movie for The Spectator.

Advertisement

Damon played Leslie Groves Jr. in "Oppenheimer" (2023).

Rating: 94%

Summary: Set during World War II, Leslie Groves Jr. (Damon) recruits physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer (Cillian Murphy) to work on the Manhattan Project. Together, they create a team of scientists to build and later detonate the first atomic bomb in history, impacting the world forever.

Although some reviews said "Oppenheimer" was longer than necessary, critics still admired the film for its monumental storyline.

"Nolan isn't interested in scaling down or tidying up. Heck, no one expects a bomb to go off cleanly, and there's plenty to sift through in 'Oppenheimer's" shrapnel,'" wrote Adam Graham for The Detroit News. "People will likely be going through it for years."

Advertisement

In "Saving Private Ryan" (1998), Damon played Private James Francis Ryan.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 94%

Summary: Set during World War II, a group of American soldiers are assigned a dangerous mission: to locate and bring back Private James Ryan (Damon), whose three brothers have been killed in combat.

The film won an Academy Award and solidified itself as one of the greatest war films ever made due to its talented cast, masterful directing, and iconic opening D-Day sequence.

"The visual masterwork finds Spielberg atop his craft, weaving heart-pounding action and gut-wrenching emotion that will leave viewers silently shaken," wrote Michael Rechtshaffen for the Hollywood Reporter.

Advertisement

"True Grit" (2010) featured Damon as the character La Boeuf.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 95%

Summary: A determined young girl seeks justice for her father's murder by enlisting the help of a grizzled U.S. Marshal (Jeff Bridges) and a Texas Ranger (Damon) to track down the killer in the harsh and unforgiving Wild West.

In addition to the film's talented cast, reviewers enjoyed the storytelling, commitment to the classic Western genre, and masterful cinematography.

"The Coen Brothers' adaptation takes a darker, more solemn approach to the subject matter, which works perfectly," wrote Cory Woodroof for Lumination Network,

Damon won an Academy Award for his role as Will Hunting in "Good Will Hunting" (1997).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 97%

Summary: A young janitor possesses an extraordinary mathematical talent that is discovered by a professor.

As an award-winning film, "Good Will Hunting" received critical acclaim for its riveting screenplay, dynamic acting from Damon and Robin Williams, and complex exploration of personal growth.

The film was described as "lyrically directed, efficiently written, side-splittingly funny, quietly devastating" by Roxana Hadadi for RogerEbert.com.

Damon narrated "Howard Zinn: You Can't Be Neutral on a Moving Train" (2004).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 97%

Summary: This documentary explores the life and work of historian and activist Howard Zinn.

Almost all of the reviews for this film were positive, with most calling it insightful and engaging.

"A provocative documentary on a life that could easily be described as a moving train," wrote Marta Barber for the Miami Herald.

Advertisement

He also narrated "Inside Job" (2010).

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 98%

Summary: This documentary dissects the 2008 global financial crisis and explores its underlying causes and systemic corruption within the financial industry.

Despite feeling the film was difficult to watch, nearly all critics thought the movie was essential viewing for those looking to understand the financial system.

"I've only scratched the surface of this intelligent, riveting and informative film, which I cannot commend too highly," wrote Philip French for The Guardian.

Advertisement

Damon also narrated the documentary "Boston" (2017), his highest-rated film.

Rotten Tomatoes Score: 100%

Summary: This documentary examines the history and significance of the Boston Marathon, focusing on the resilience of the city and its people in the face of tragedy.

The critics who reviewed "Boston" overwhelmingly enjoyed it, feeling it poignantly captured the city's pride and offered a unique insight into the world of running and the history of the Boston Marathon.

"'Boston,' like the city itself, is strong indeed," wrote Daphne Howland for the Village Voice.
